article.title: Learning from Higgs Physics at Future Higgs Factories

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the left panel of Figure 1 show?
choices: The allowed range of the mixing angle θ for different values of cHv²/Λ².
The allowed range of cHv²/Λ² for different values of the mixing angle θ.
The Δχ² as a function of the singlet-SM Higgs doublet mixing angle |sin θ| in the Z₂-breaking case for different Higgs factories.
The Δχ² as a function of cHv²/Λ² for different Higgs factories.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the vertical dashed lines in the right panel of Figure 1 indicate?
choices: The maximum allowed values for the singlet-doublet mixing angle |sin θ|.
The allowed range of c6v²/Λ² for different values of the mixing angle θ.
The one-parameter fit limit on cHv²/Λ² with c6 set to 0.
The maximum allowed values for the changes to trilinear Higgs coupling Δλ₃/λSM₃.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which Higgs factory has the strongest constraint on the singlet-doublet mixing angle |sin θ|?
choices: CEPC
ILC
FCC-ee
All three have similar constraints.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the relationship between the sign of the OH operator and the Higgs couplings in the presence of a real scalar singlet?
choices: The sign of OH is negative, leading to an increase in Higgs couplings.
The sign of OH can be either positive or negative, leading to either an increase or decrease in Higgs couplings.
The sign of OH is positive semi-definite, leading to a decrease in Higgs couplings.
There is no direct relationship between the sign of OH and the Higgs couplings.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the shaded regions in Figure 2 represent?
choices: The allowed region in the plane of tan β vs. cos(β-α) at 90% C.L. for different types of 2HDM.
The allowed region in the plane of tan β vs. cos(β-α) at 95% C.L. for different types of 2HDM.
The excluded region in the plane of tan β vs. cos(β-α) at 90% C.L. for different types of 2HDM.
The excluded region in the plane of tan β vs. cos(β-α) at 95% C.L. for different types of 2HDM.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which type of 2HDM allows the largest deviation from the alignment limit (cos(β-α) = 0)?
choices: Type-I
Type-II
Type-L
Type-F

multiple_choice_question.text: What causes the "arm" regions observed in Figure 2 for Type-II, Type-L, and Type-F 2HDMs?
choices: Large deviations in the up-type Yukawa couplings.
Small deviations in the down-type and lepton Yukawa couplings.
Wrong-sign Yukawa couplings.
Loop corrections from heavy Higgs bosons.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which Higgs decay channel typically provides the strongest constraints on the 2HDM parameter space?
choices: h → γγ
h → ττ
h → bb and h → VV (V=W, Z)
h → μμ

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 6 show?
choices: 90% C.L. constraints on the tan β vs. mφ plane for different types of 2HDM.
95% C.L. constraints on the tan β vs. mφ plane for different types of 2HDM.
Excluded regions in the tan β vs. mφ plane at 90% C.L. for different types of 2HDM.
Excluded regions in the tan β vs. mφ plane at 95% C.L. for different types of 2HDM.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the parameter  √λv² represent in this context?
choices: √λv² ≡ √(m²φ - m²₁₂/(sinβcosβ))
√λv² ≡ √(m²φ + m²₁₂/(sinβcosβ))
√λv² ≡ √(m²₁₂ - m²φ/(sinβcosβ))
√λv² ≡ √(m²₁₂ + m²φ/(sinβcosβ))

multiple_choice_question.text: For Type-I 2HDM, what values of tan β are disfavored by the heavy Higgs loop corrections?
choices: Small values of tan β ≤ 0.5
Large values of tan β ≥ 5
Values of tan β around 1
All values of tan β are equally constrained.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary reason for the stronger constraints on the heavy Higgs masses at large tan β for Type-II, Type-L, and Type-F 2HDMs compared to Type-I?
choices: The presence of top quark threshold effects in the relevant loop diagrams.
The larger number of heavy Higgs bosons contributing to the loop corrections.
The tan β enhancement of the down-type and lepton Yukawa couplings.
The weaker experimental precision on the h → bb and h → ττ channels.

multiple_choice_question.text: What kind of fit is used to generate the constraints shown in Figure 11?
choices: A one-parameter fit with ξ as the fitting parameter.
A four-parameter fit with κV, κt, κc, and κb as fitting parameters.
A seven-parameter fit with all relevant Higgs couplings as fitting parameters.
A global fit including all relevant Higgs couplings and electroweak precision observables.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the magenta line in Figure 11 represent?
choices: The predicted deviation of κt and κV for MCHM with κt=F2.
The predicted deviation of κt and κV for MCHM with κt=F1.
The predicted deviation of κt and κV for MCHM with κt=F3,4,5.
The 95% C.L. limit from LHC 300 fb⁻¹.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary reason for the significantly better constraints on MCHM parameters at future lepton colliders compared to the LHC?
choices: The much better determination of the Higgs couplings to gauge bosons at lepton colliders.
The higher center of mass energy reach of lepton colliders.
The cleaner experimental environment at lepton colliders.
The larger integrated luminosity achievable at lepton colliders.

multiple_choice_question.text: For MCHM with κt=F3,4,5, what is the impact of the variation of additional model parameters on the correlation between ΔκV and Δκt?
choices: The correlation is independent of the variation of additional model parameters.
The correlation is only weakly affected by the variation of additional model parameters.
The predicted range of ΔκV and Δκt is broadened due to the variation of additional model parameters.
The predicted range of ΔκV and Δκt is narrowed down due to the variation of additional model parameters.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 12 show?
choices: The 90% C.L. constraints on the overall coefficient of Oi from Ref. [34].
The 95% C.L. constraints on the overall coefficient of Oi from Ref. [34].
The allowed ranges of m∗/√ci for different Higgs factories.
The projected sensitivities of different Higgs factories to individual EFT operators.

multiple_choice_question.text: What are the three "typical patterns" of strong dynamics considered in this analysis?
choices: ALH, GSILH, and SILH
MCHM, 2HDM, and SM + Singlet
Type-I, Type-II, and Type-L 2HDM
OH, OGG, and OW

multiple_choice_question.text: In the global fit, which operator typically provides the strongest constraint on the new physics scale m∗?
choices: OH for all three strong dynamics cases.
Oyb for ALH at CEPC/FCC-ee and OH for ALH at ILC; Oyb for GSILH and SILH.
OGG for all three strong dynamics cases.
OW for all three strong dynamics cases.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is the reach in m∗ for the OGG operator significantly better for ALH compared to GSILH and SILH?
choices: The larger estimated coupling size for OGG in ALH.
The absence of loop suppression for OGG in ALH due to the lack of shift-symmetry.
The stronger constraints from diphoton measurements at HL-LHC for ALH.
The smaller number of free parameters in the global fit for ALH.
